data: Honorific for Titianus on the occasion of his assumption of the toga virilis
Large rectangular stele, of local grey limestone, well-squared but with abrasions and wear on sides, and damage to top as top edge abraded. Rear is relatively smooth. Small decorative band at bottom.

Eight lines of continuous Latin text. Text fills most of stone, with stone-carver attempting to centre text onto stone. Upright hedera in line 4, with right-facing tail. Two final lines smaller.  Occasional use of interpuncts, in lines 1, 2, 5 and 6: tick-shaped in line 1, and more Y-shaped in subsequent lines. Some sort of interpunct/squiggle in line 8. Representing a pointed tilde (~)
Letters are tall and elongated. Ornate serifs used on every letter. Letters extremely regular and spacing between letters is consistent.
The stone was already walled into the townhall of Termini Imerese when recorded by Gualtherus in 1624
Antoniou, 2022-07-08. On display in the courtyard portico of Museo Civico Baldassare Romano
I.Sicily with the permission of the Assessorato Regionale dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana - Dipartimento dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana; photo J. Prag 08-07-2022
honorific for titianus on the occasion of his assumption of the toga virilis

3rd century CE on prosopographical grounds (but difficult to pin down more tightly) - so too Barbieri
Encoded following the latest EpiDoc guidelines
James Cummings autogenerated EpiDoc output from database
Tuuli Ahlholm cleaned up the autogenerated text and added an apparatus and translation
Simona Stoyanova updated list of languages
edition on basis of autopsy and photographs
Jonathan Prag revised images and minor edits
Contra Mommsen, no interpunct on stone after 'et' on line 2
Contra Mommsen, No interpunct on stone after 'ob' on line 5
Contra Mommsen, no interpunct on stone after '-rem' on line 6,

Against the standard reading, autopsy reveals Rusus on stone, rather than Rufus. Contra Mommsen, no interpuncts on stone after every word, except for oddly shaped interpunct between 'suo' and 'incomparabile' in line 8
Detailed palaeographic study and comparison across the Fs and Ss in the inscription reveal that the name is definitely Rufus.
Against the standard reading, autopsy reveals incomparabile rather than incomparabili

To Titianus, the most illustrious son of Gaius Maesius Titianus and Fonteia Frontina (both) of consular rank, son of patrician birth. In honour (of his assumption) of the toga virilis. Clodius Rusus, a Roman knight, (made this) to his incomparable friend.

As Dessau (ILS) emphasises, c(larissimo) f(ilio) in line 1 is unusual, as c(larissimo) i(uveni) is more standard. Dessau also notes that it is rare for someone to be explicitly qualified as belonging to the patrician class, unless they were adlected into that class. As Bivona (1994, 122) summarises, it is possible that the father of the dedicatee, Gaius Maesius Titianus, is the consul ordinarius of 245 CE, who held the office alongside the emperor M. Iulius Philippus, and who was himself possibly the son of the Maesius Fabius Titianus, c(larissimus) p(uer) of , a dedication which was securely made between December 197-December 198 CE based on imperial titulature. The mother is likely a descendant of D. Fonteius Frontinianus (L. Stertinius Rufus) the legate of Numidia from 160-162 CE. As Bivona (1994, 122-123) stresses, the title of consularis (the Latin equivalent of the Greek ὑπατική) attested for women is extremely rare, and is epigraphically attested from only the period between 211-250 CE. Another Gaius Maesius is attested at Thermae Himeraeae, see . While Salinas (NSA 1884, 163) identified the dedicator as P. Clodius Rufus Latro, who dedicated an honorific to Tiberius found in the area of Capo d'Orlando, see , the autopsied reading of the cognomen Rusus makes this less certain (although not impossible). Members of the gens Clodia are attested elsewhere in Sicily.
ISic000093. Honorific for Titianus on the occasion of his assumption of the toga virilis

  • Detailed palaeographic study and comparison across the Fs and Ss in the inscription reveal that the name is definitely Rufus.
  • 8: Against the standard reading, autopsy reveals incomparabile rather than incomparabili

English translation

To Titianus, the most illustrious son of Gaius Maesius Titianus and Fonteia Frontina (both) of consular rank, son of patrician birth. In honour (of his assumption) of the toga virilis. Clodius Rusus, a Roman knight, (made this) to his incomparable friend.

commentary

As Dessau (ILS) emphasises, c(larissimo) f(ilio) in line 1 is unusual, as c(larissimo) i(uveni) is more standard. Dessau also notes that it is rare for someone to be explicitly qualified as belonging to the patrician class, unless they were adlected into that class. As Bivona (1994, 122) summarises, it is possible that the father of the dedicatee, Gaius Maesius Titianus, is the consul ordinarius of 245 CE, who held the office alongside the emperor M. Iulius Philippus, and who was himself possibly the son of the Maesius Fabius Titianus, c(larissimus) p(uer) of ISic000091, a dedication which was securely made between December 197-December 198 CE based on imperial titulature. The mother is likely a descendant of D. Fonteius Frontinianus (L. Stertinius Rufus) the legate of Numidia from 160-162 CE. As Bivona (1994, 122-123) stresses, the title of consularis (the Latin equivalent of the Greek ὑπατική) attested for women is extremely rare, and is epigraphically attested from only the period between 211-250 CE. Another Gaius Maesius is attested at Thermae Himeraeae, see ISic000092. While Salinas (NSA 1884, 163) identified the dedicator as P. Clodius Rufus Latro, who dedicated an honorific to Tiberius found in the area of Capo d'Orlando, see ISic003339, the autopsied reading of the cognomen Rusus makes this less certain (although not impossible). Members of the gens Clodia are attested elsewhere in Sicily.
